SENT.plain: Strokes are rarely secondary to spontaneous carotid artery thrombosis
The objectives of this retrospective analysis were to define characteristic features and the clinical course
The study population included eight patients (6 females/2 males) seen at six university neurological centers
Half of the patients had no vascular risk factor
Echotomography revealed intraluminal thrombus, with occlusion in 2 cases
Thrombi were found in common carotid artery (n=3), carotid bifurcation (n=2) and internal carotid artery (n=3)
The thrombus was mobile in 4 cases
Seven patients were treated by anticoagulation therapy, one by surgery because of recurrent TIA
Further echotomographic exams revealed total resolution (3 cases) or decrease of the thrombus (3 cases)
Occlusion was definitive in one patient
A cause was identified in six patients: acute leukemia (n=1), thrombocytopenic purpura (n=1), iron deficiency anemia (n=4)
